title: Reed Krakoff on Tiffany’s Past and Future
text:
Text size

Everyone loves a great comeback story, which is why the fashion world has followed the trajectory of luxury brandmeister Reed Krakoff with such enthusiasm.

Headlines have tracked the creative director’s rise (resuscitating Tommy Hilfiger, then transforming Coach from forgettable handbag also-ran to international megabrand), then fall (Krakoff’s own namesake label launched in 2009 with much fanfare and shuttered in 2015), and now rise (he assumed the newly created role of chief artistic officer at Tiffany & Co. in 2017, brought in with CEO Alessandro Bogliolo to refresh the 182-year-old brand).

Krakoff, 55, may be new to the world of jewelry but not to the aura of Tiffany. Born to a wealthy family in Weston, Conn., he and his wife, Delphine, an interior designer, and their four children today split their time between a mansion in tony New Canaan, Conn., and a Manhattan townhouse.

Penta decided to check in with Krakoff, now that he’s had time to settle in at Tiffany. He admits there’s been a learning curve. Yet despite the ongoing, unpredictable U.S.-China trade war and softening spending by Chinese tourists, Tiffany’s worldwide net sales rose 7% to $4.4 billion last year.

Penta: Since your arrival, what has surprised you most about the brand?

Reed Krakoff: There are probably a couple of answers. I grew up with the brand, but didn’t realize the magnitude of it. People have a deep love of its history. Then there’s the level of commitment to craftsmanship. There are no shortcuts, whether it’s a sterling silver keychain or a $20 million 100-carat yellow diamond. That’s something you can forget about when brands get big.

You’ve been brought in to change things—but not too much!

Right, no problem. [He laughs.] That’s the forever question—how do you move forward without losing what made the brand arguably the most desirable brand in the world? There’s trial and error, a lot of exploration. I’m very fortunate, as Tiffany’s first creative director, to be able to bring different areas [of the company] together; to tell our story in a unified way. So, if there’s a new collection, it may spark an idea for store interiors, which leads to marketing, which leads to events—everything works together. It’s a different way of working in the jewelry business. It’s more typical of the fashion world.

Tiffany is perhaps the only brand that evokes such a powerful connection to a color—Tiffany blue. You see a box in that iconic shade and it says so much. What is it about that shade that makes it so recognizable?

I don’t think there’s a simple answer. Tiffany has been around many, many, many years, and the experience people have had at Tiffany of finding something to commemorate a pivotal moment in their lives [has been repeated] over and over. You know, a color is a color but this is imbued with such a sense of excitement.

Can you imagine changing the shade? Updating it?

“ I’m working in the service of an incredible brand. That’s first and foremost what I think about. ” —Reed Krakoff

No. It’s what every brand dreams to have. It has to be treated with respect.

Let’s talk about Tiffany’s annual Blue Book Collection.

It’s become a laboratory for our most forward-thinking and fantastical designs. It’s the place where ideas begin and are later adapted to the more commercial collection. It’s the place to dream. A recent example of that: We developed a new stone-cutting technique. It took almost a year to make one piece—a small piece—because of its scale and intricacy. It’s as if you had a sheet of diamonds that were fragmented and cracked, with very minimal space between each one. So each stone has to be cut and linked to the next, which is just enormously difficult to do. People weren’t sure we could do it.

[The technique was used in several 2019 Blue Book pieces, including a dragonfly brooch with more than seven carats of custom-cut diamonds, and a 16-plus carat diamond choker debuted by Lady Gaga at this year’s Screen Actors Guild Awards.]

Each piece is like a little sculpture. How does the process for a new work begin?

I don’t really believe in spending a lot of time on inspiration boards. I get inspired as I’m working. We start with more an attitude, sort of a feel.

People dress more casually now. Does that worry you?

One of the things making us unique is that we create pieces that are meant to be worn.

As opposed to being stored away…

Exactly.

…and only brought out on special occasions?

These are valuable pieces, but should be part of your wardrobe. That’s what American style is about.

Do you use yourself as a guidepost? You’re launching a new men’s collection this fall. Have you been asking, “Would I wear that?”

It’s an interesting question. I’m not someone who wears jewelry at all. I have one ring made in the shape of a rubber band, and that’s the only thing I wear. It’s my wedding band.

What? You’re an impostor, sir!

But…[he chuckles]. I’ve always found it’s more intuition. I’m working in the service of an incredible brand. That’s first and foremost what I think about. How does [any new piece] move forward the idea of Tiffany? How does this fit in historically? And how does this take advantage of what Tiffany can do uniquely? All those things come into play.
description: The designer became the brand’s chief artistic officer in 2017
